abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Agriculture Support
            Services Project for Tunisia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            significant, Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the benefits of a comprehensive
            project design can be outweighed by complexity, difficulty
            in implementation, and resources being spread too thin, even
            in a middle-income country like Tunisia. The effectiveness
            of complex projects implemented by multiple actors can be
            undermined unless the project management unit (or its parent
            agency) has sufficient authority to proactively coordinate
            key implementation agencies. Attempts to move from public to
            private provision of services can be undermined if there is
            not sufficient attention to beneficiary, needs, perceptions,
            and incentives, both for producers and service providers.
            Lack of ownership of producer associations by farmers limits
            their utility in providing farmers with inputs, access to
            services and inserting their interests into agricultural policy.

17985159.trustfund: BBFAO-BB FAO,TF025459-PHRD-AGRICULTURE SUPPORT SERVICES,TF030333-FRENCH AGRICULTURE CTF FY03 - MENA
17985159.majtheme: Rural development,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Agricultural Support
            Services Project for Tunisia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory.  Some lessons learned included: the project
            concentrated too much on cooperatives as a vehicle to help
            farmers. It neglected private marketing intermediaries,
            which were already providing some of the desired services
            (advice and help on variety selection, inputs, cultivation,
            harvest, post harvest handling, help on marketing, pest
            control, and in some cases credit). An analysis should have
            been done to identify several value chains for each product.
            Then each sector should have received assistance, beginning
            at the farm level, by looking to the end market and finding
            out exactly what buyers would pay for. Farm level actions
            could have been subsidized in part at the outset for newly
            created value chains, moving toward cost recovery after a
            transition period for the private sector value chains as
            they became well established. Competitiveness of Tunisian
            products is a matter of both quality and price. Quality
            standards are now better controlled thanks to several
            activities of the project through partnerships between
            importers and Tunisians processors, improved regulations,
            better laboratory infrastructure, and information
            management. The remaining challenge is to maintain a price
            that is competitive for both the increasingly demanding
            local market and the export market. However, the marketing
            of agricultural produce is currently characterized by
            controls of some food prices at the wholesale level,
            administrative controls of marketing margins and
            insufficient clarity in wholesale market transactions. This
            environment does not provide the right incentives for
            producers to address quality issues, as quality is often
            associated with higher costs that they might not be able to
            recuperate. Unless the current marketing practices do not
            change, improvements in quality as a result of better
            service delivery will not materialize.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisie - Projet de Renforcement des
            Services d'Appui a l'Agriculture : etude
            d'impact sur l'environnement

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment reviews
            the negative impacts on the environment, resulting from the
            implementation of the Agriculture Support Services Project,
            whose development objectives are the promotion of productive
            agriculture, to facilitate Tunisia's integration within
            an international commercial context, and, to improve the
            living standards of agricultural producers. Following the
            country's environmental legal, and regulatory
            framework, adverse impacts, and mitigation measures
            stipulate the following. Agricultural research, risks the
            exploitation of rare, and vulnerable resources, such as
            soil, and water degradation: an evaluation of environmental
            aspects will be conducted, by developing criteria for the
            selection of research projects, supported by regional, and
            national commissions on research programs. Domestic water
            uses, and contaminated effluents due to the use of
            chemicals, may threaten the vegetation's toxicity
            levels, including human, and animal health : sewage networks
            will divert domestic water usage, preventing soil
            contamination. Likewise, laboratory discharges, solid
            wastes, and/or lubricants, will be either incinerated, or
            disposed of in accordance with the Sewerage Authority's
            (ONAS) regulations. The use of pesticides, and fertilizers
            may endanger natural resources, and human health: guidelines
            will be prepared for an optimal use of these products, and,
            information on integrated pest management will be
            disseminated. Genetic losses due to artificial insemination
            may occur: coordination with national institutions, should
            identify strategic programs for the conservation of
            biological native diversity.

1121290.admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa
1121290.subsc: Agricultural extension and research,Agro-industry, marketing, and trade,Central government administration,Animal production

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Support Services
            Project aims to develop, on a pilot basis, organizational
            structures for producers that represent their needs and
            interests; and improve the institutional capacity and
            quality of agricultural services delivered by public and
            private institutions and producer organizations; and improve
            the flow of information for all stakeholders. The project
            consists of five components: 1) This component will support
            capacity building for producers organizations (both local
            and national) and inter-professional organizations to
            improve market access and provide, manage, and finance
            services to their members. 2) This component will support
            public, cooperative, and private services that deliver
            producer services focused on increasing quality, value
            added, and market access. 3) This component will support
            public, cooperative, and private services that deliver
            producer services to livestock producers, with particular
            focus on improving quality of services and their
            sustainability through progressive transfer and cost
            recovery. 4) This component will aim at protecting Tunisian
            produce from plant diseases and predators, and at protecting
            consumers from pesticide residues, and thereby increasing
            the value and market access of produce. 5) This component
            will maximize the coverage, reliability, and availability of
            statistics and information for all parties making choices
            affecting the sector. It will also support project management.
